I am watching this video for the second time and I have come to question the date 1918. it COULD be correct, particularly since as you say the piece did come from Germany. In which case it's history would be quite unique. As far as I know in general, aluminum riveted aircraft skins were not developed until 1929 in the USA with the one exception of the WWI German Junkers J-1 which did use riveted aluminium. My great uncle flew combat aircraft in WWI. The air frames he was in ( British, French, American, German) weren't riveted aluminium. I don't know if he ever flew the Junkers, but he did fly pretty much everything that was flying at the time because one of his jobs was to ferry captured enemy aircraft back to the U.K for assessment. He was also a test pilot. You may suck at welding because you are using a MIG. With an incorrect MIG gas aluminium just won't weld properly, it must be 100% argon OR 75% argon/25% helium, where as to weld steel the mix is 75% argon/25% carbon dioxide. TIG is the usual choice for aluminium and stainless. What I respectfully suggest is that you acquire a small oxyacetylene set and a micro torch (a jewelers torch), and some low temperature aluminium welding rod. The torch and the rod can be obtained from eBay at VERY reasonable prices. You might also instead acquire a torch known as a "Henrob" torch or as I believe they are now known a "Cobra "torch. It is also a micro torch but is more expensive but will be of much higher quality. It is also more ergonomic in design. With this set up you can cut and weld mild steel, stainless steel, aluminium and other metals. This option is MUCH cheaper than buying a dedicated TIG welder. I'm sure that your friend is aware of all this.....The first time I watched this video I commented that the riveter would make a good planishing hammer because of the hammer head face design. It occurs to me that you certainly have skills and the means to make a selection of hammers for this piece,  in which case the tool will become even more useful as a shaping hammer. It is rather unfortunate however that you polished off the hammer designation and serial numbers.

I am an aircraft sheet metal mechanic and use these on a daily basis. Before each use, place a few drops of tool oil and it will last forever. Also the part at the end held with the spring is called the set. They are interchangeable for different jobs. That one is a flat set for flush style rivets and general hammering. You should get some button head, chisel and punch sets to go along with it. Great job.

If you boil parts in water for a half hour it will convert the red rust into a very strong black oxide. This black oxide will be much stronger than the cold blue (which is a black colored copper that you wipe on) that you used. Once it's been boiled you have to use 0000 steel wool or a gunsmiths carding wheel.

On those welds, I could tell just by listening to the audio that you'd benefit from a foot pedal. With aluminum, you need really tight control on the amperage. Additionally, it seemed to me you need to run a high CFM on the gas. Either you need to run a different, tighter gas lens, or you need to up your flow rate and get a new lens. Overall, it seems like you're blowing through, and you're getting a lot of oxidation which can be fixed simply by increasing gas flow.

Check out the fabrication series youtube channel: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCcxlBLmujrjTVSSUkzZ2Jlg

These guys have some really good content that can help normal guys become great welders. I would watch his videos on welding thin walled aluminum tubing, since you could apply a lot of that information to the welds you're putting down and get a notable improvement.
